intro: Quinchamalium chilense var. majus, commonly known as the Chilean quinchamalium, is a flowering plant native to southern Chile. It belongs to the family Polygonaceae, which includes plants known for their distinctive bracts and often edible roots. The plant features upright stems with broad, lance-shaped leaves that are often covered in a fine, silky hair. Its showy, pinkish-white flowers appear in clusters and bloom in the spring, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Due to its ornamental value and ecological importance, it is sometimes cultivated in gardens and conservation areas.
